transcripts.text: So we're here with Steve from the Bullion Brothers and today you're going to show us how to tell if some jewelry is actually gold or not.  Is that right, Steve?
Alright, so down here we have some jewelry and what's the first step to tell?

The first step to tell is a magnet, something that most people are going to have at home, something that's readily available, or you can easily acquire one.  We like to go with a high-power magnet.  This is a neodymium magnet.  It's got about a 35-pound pull to it.  You're going to want a high-power magnet to make sure that you're testing for any metallic or ferrous substance inside that jewelry or material.  gold or whatever it is that you got.
If you do use one of these, how much do they go for?
Where would you find one?  You can pick one of these up online for anywhere between $40 to $50, I would imagine.  Okay.  Under $40.
Okay.  All right, so why don't you show us how this...

So again, gold is non-magnetic, so you're going to be able to run your magnet over the gold, and it should have almost no reaction.  Now, if the gold moves a little bit, that's all right, because the gold's actually slightly diamagnetic, which means it's going to repel a magnet ever so slightly.  So if it moves just a little bit, that's okay.  but it should not attract to the magnet in any way, shape, or form.  Now, every now and again, you'll see the clasps do have some steel or some metal inside of them, so generally speaking, those clasps will stick.  If you notice, I'm purposefully going over the clasps so you can see what that looks like.  But for the most part, these guys should not stick to a magnet in any way, shape, or form.  Now, when we get to the fake stuff, it's pretty obvious what happens.  Again, the fake stuff... just doesn't.
so it's sticking because the non-golden silver is is magnetic inside whatever.

so basically you get a magnet and if it sticks no bueno that's correct.  no bueno but if it's gold or silver you'll just see uh like like you saw on that this piece right here that there was no reaction.

Further testing would be required to make sure that this is actually gold that we're working with.  But if we know if it sticks, it's not gold.  And even if it's plated gold, there's no value in the plating.
All right.  And we're going to make a video now of how to do the acid test.  So if you did want to follow that up, just click on that one and you'll know how to do that.
